pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing expulsion
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:0.4: 4. The fourth training rule on expulsion
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.2: At that time a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence on the banks of the river Vaggumudā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.3: Just then Vajjī was short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.4: and it was not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.5: The monks considered the difficult circumstances, and they thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.6: “How can we remain united and in harmony, have a comfortable rainy season,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.10: and they’ll give something in return.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.11: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rainy season in comfort
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.12: and have no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.14: “There’s no need to work for the householders.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.15: Let’s instead take messages for them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.16: and they’ll give something in return.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.17: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rainy season in comfort
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.18: and have no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.20: “There’s no need to work for the householders,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.21: nor to take messages for them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.22: Let’s instead praise one another’s superhuman qualities to the householders:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.23: ‘Such a monk has the first absorption,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.24: such a monk the second absorption,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.27: such a monk is a stream-enterer,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.31: such a monk has the three true insights,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.32: and such the six direct knowledges.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.34: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rainy season in comfort
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.35: and have no trouble getting almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.36: Indeed, this is the better way, that we praise one another’s superhuman qualities to the householders.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.37: Then those monks praised one another’s superhuman qualities to the householders:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.38: “Such a monk has the first absorption …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.39: such a monk has the six direct knowledges.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.41: “We’re fortunate that such monks have come to us for the rainy-season residence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.42: Such monks as these, who are virtuous and of good character, have never before entered the rains residence with us.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.43: And they gave such food and drink to those monks that they did not even eat and drink themselves, or give to their parents, to their wives and children, to their slaves, servants, and workers, to their friends and companions, or to their relatives.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.1.45: In this way those monks were satisfied, with a good color, a bright face, and clear skin.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.1: Now it was the custom for monks who had completed the rainy-season residence to go and visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.2: So when they had completed the rains residence and the three months had elapsed, those monks put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and left for Vesālī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.3: When they eventually arrived at Vesālī, they went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood. There they approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.4: At that time the monks who had completed the rains residence in that region were thin, haggard, and pale, their veins protruding all over their limbs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.5: But the monks from the banks of the Vaggumudā were satisfied, with a good color, a bright face, and clear skin.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.6: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.8: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re comfortable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.9: I hope you had a comfortable rains residence, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and that you had no trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.10: “We’re keeping well, Venerable Sir, we’re comfortable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.11: we had a comfortable rains residence, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and we had no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.12: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not; they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask. Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial, for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.13: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.14: And the Buddha said to those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.15: “In what way, monks, did you have a comfortable rains residence, without having any trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.16: Then those monks told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.17: “But had you really achieved those superhuman qualities?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.20: “It’s not suitable, foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s should not be done.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.21: How can you for the sake of your stomachs praise one another’s superhuman qualities to householders?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.22: It would be better for your bellies to be cut open with a sharp butcher’s knife than for you to praise one another’s superhuman qualities to householders.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.24: Because for that reason you might die or experience death-like suffering,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.25: but you wouldn’t because of that be reborn in a bad destination.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.27: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.2.28: After rebuking them and giving a teaching, he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.1: “Monks, there are these five great gangsters to be found in the world.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.3: A great gangster thinks like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.4: ‘Oh when will I, with a following of a hundred or a thousand men, wander among villages, towns, and royal capitals,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.5: killing and making others kill, destroying and making others destroy, tormenting and making others torment?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.6: Then after some time, he does just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.7: Just so, monks, a bad monk thinks like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.8: ‘Oh when will I, with a following of a hundred or a thousand people, go wandering among villages, towns, and royal capitals;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.9: be honored, respected, and revered by both lay people and those gone forth; and obtain robes, almsfood, dwellings, and medicines?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.10: Then after some time, he does just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.11: This is the first great gangster to be found in the world.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.12: Again, a bad monk learns the spiritual path proclaimed by the Buddha and takes it as his own.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.13: This is the second great gangster to be found in the world.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.14: Again, a bad monk groundlessly charges someone who lives the spiritual life in purity with not abstaining from sexuality.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.15: This is the third great gangster to be found in the world.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.16: Again, a bad monk takes valuable goods and requisites belonging to the Sangha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.17: a monastery, the site of a monastery, a dwelling, the site of a dwelling, a bed, a bench, a mattress, a pillow, a metal pot, a metal jar, a metal bucket, a metal bowl, a machete, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, a chisel, a creeper, bamboo, reed, grass, clay, wooden goods, earthenware goods—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.18: and uses them to win over and create a following among householders.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.19: This is the fourth great gangster to be found in the world.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.20: But in this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, in this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, this is the greatest gangster: one who untruthfully and groundlessly boasts about a superhuman quality.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.22: Monks, you’ve eaten the country’s almsfood by theft.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.24: to be other than he truly is,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.26: like a cheater who has deceived.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.31: It’s better to eat an iron ball,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.33: Than for the immoral and uncontrolled
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.35: After rebuking the monks from the banks of the Vaggumudā in many ways for being difficult to maintain, difficult to support …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.36: “… And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.37.1: ‘If a monk falsely claims for himself a superhuman quality, knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, saying, “This I know, this I see,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.38: but after some time—whether questioned or not, but having committed the offense and seeking purification—should say: “Not knowing I said that I know, not seeing that I see; what I said was empty and false,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.39: he too is expelled and excluded from the community.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:1.3.40: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.1: At one time a number of monks, thinking they had seen what they had not, attained what they had not, achieved what they had not, realized what they had not, declared final knowledge because of overestimation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.2: After some time, their minds inclined to sensual desire, ill will, and confusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.4: “The Buddha has laid down a training rule,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.5: yet we declared final knowledge because of overestimation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.6: Could it be that we’ve committed an offense entailing expulsion?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.9: He said, “Ānanda, these monks declared final knowledge because of overestimation, thinking they had seen what they had not, attained what they had not, achieved what they had not, realized what they had not,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.11: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.12.1: ‘If a monk falsely claims for himself a superhuman quality, knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, saying, “This I know, this I see,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.13: but after some time—whether he is questioned or not, but having committed the offense and seeking purification—should say: “Not knowing I said that I know, not seeing that I see; what I said was empty and false,” then,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.14: except if it is due to overestimation,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:2.15: he too is expelled and excluded from the community.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.2: while Venerable Lakkhaṇa and Venerable Mahāmoggallāna were staying on the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.3: One morning Mahāmoggallāna robed up, took his bowl and robe, approached Lakkhaṇa, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.6: As they were descending from the Vulture Peak, Mahāmoggallāna smiled at a certain place.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.9: “This isn’t the right time to reply.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.1.10: Please ask me in the presence of the Buddha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.1: Then, after their meal and after returning from almsround, Lakkhaṇa and Mahāmoggallāna approached the Buddha
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.4: “Just now, as you were descending from the Vulture Peak, you smiled at a certain place.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.6: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a skeleton flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.7: Vultures, crows, and hawks were in close pursuit of it, striking it between the ribs,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.8: while it uttered cries of distress.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.10: how amazing and astonishing it is that such a being should exist,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.13: The monks complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.14: “Venerable Mahāmoggallāna is claiming a superhuman ability.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.15: The Buddha then said to them:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.18: and they can see, know, and witness such things.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.19: I too, monks, have seen that being,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.20: but I didn’t speak about it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.21: If I had, others wouldn’t have believed me,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.22: and that would have been for their harm and suffering for a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.23: That being was a cattle-butcher in this very Rājagaha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.2.24: As a result of his deeds, he was tormented in hell for many years, for many hundreds of years, for many thousands of years, for many hundreds of thousands of years. And now, because of the remaining result of his actions, he’s experiencing such an existence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.1: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a lump of flesh flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.2: Vultures, crows, and hawks were in close pursuit of it, tearing at it and pulling it to pieces,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.3: while it uttered cries of distress. …” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.4: “… That being, monks, was a cattle-butcher in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.5: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a morsel of flesh flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.6: Vultures, crows, and hawks were in close pursuit of it, tearing at it and pulling it to pieces,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.7: while it uttered cries of distress. …” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.8: “… That being, monks, was a poultry-butcher in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.9: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a flayed man flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.10: Vultures, crows, and hawks were in close pursuit of him, tearing at him and pulling him to pieces,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.11: while he uttered cries of distress. …” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.12: “… That being, monks, was a sheep-butcher in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.13: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a man who had body hairs of swords flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.14: Again and again he was stabbed by those swords,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.16: “… That being, monks, was a butcher of pigs in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.17: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a man with body hairs of knives flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.18: Again and again he was stabbed by those knives,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.20: “… That being, monks, was a deer-hunter in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.21: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a man with body hairs of arrows flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.22: Again and again he was pierced by those arrows,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.24: “… That being, monks, was a torturer in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.25: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a man with body hairs of needles flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.26: Again and again he was pierced by those needles,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.28: “… That being, monks, was a horse trainer in this very Rājagaha. …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.29: “As I was coming down from the Vulture Peak, I saw a man with body hairs of needles flying through the air.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.30: Those needles pierced his head and came out through his mouth,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4:9.3.31: entered his mouth and came out through his breast,
